transcript.content: Arthur Carter Transcription REDACTIONS FINAL

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: My name is Arthur Carter my date of birth is 10th October 1963 I was convicted of second degree murder in 1988 and I've served 30 years in Angola.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Wow, so you were 24 years old. I'm going to start I'm going to ask you a few questions about your time before coming here.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: I was 24 years old when I was convicted.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So I'm going to ask you a few questions about before that.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And then obviously you've gone through all kind of changes in 30 years we want to try to capture a little bit of that too.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So can you tell me a little bit about where you grew up who your family was and who took care of you? Who raised you?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: I grew up in New Orleans from an area of New Orleans called the 9th Ward. Mom and Dad raised me I was raised practically the first 17 years of my life with a little sister 4 years younger than me. Mom is in the house my dad was in the house. My dad worked as a paint contractor, my mom was like a stay-at-home mom and after about like 17 years old my dad and my mom became pregnant with my little brother. So I have a little brother that's like 17 years younger than I am and a sister that's 3 years younger than me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and would it be accurate to say that you were raised in a nurturing caring environment?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Yes sir I would say that I would say that 100% I would say that the circumstances of my life are so much different than a lot of guys that I'm doing time. Talk about all these broken childhoods and stuff my dad like I said he was a painting contractor he always stayed at work we wouldn't see him till like 4 or 5 in the evening. My mom was there I would come home from school she'd be there with lunch or whatever we would just go in front of the TV watch cartoons.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: At some point be outside playing until my dad come home, once he takes his bath and stuff she'd call us and from outside and we'd all have dinner together. Yeah I came from a very nurturing loving family.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Was the relationship between your parents good?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Excellent my mom would like always being a part of our lives she was really the go to everyday. Dad was like, that the dad you go to him when you really really need something mom tell you go tell your dad. When he came home from work he greeted us hugged us he showed us love by always giving us the thing that he thought we wanted to have and stuff like that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So what about outside the home was there a lot of fighting in your growing up?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Not necessarily we uh we didn't stay in the projects I know the 9th Ward is kind of like a hard area but we stayed I lived on Independence and Galvez.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I remember that.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: But there was no fighting periodically might fight over football or basketball game there was no gang fighting or anything my friends stayed around the corner on Congress and Galvez I was on the independence and Galvez. We just kind of like went from one street to the next playing and that's it. I mean it wasn't no like robberies or gang violence my life nothing I thought I remember this was back in the seventies too.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah I know exactly where you're talking about.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What about friends did you have some best friends that you stayed?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Yeah my first cousin Steven Hutchins that was like he was like a brother and a friend who is like my closest friend I had other friends right there the down the street from me on Independence Jeronicus that was his name. He had a brother named Willie, the friends I had around the corner Williams his brother Jimmy we just all grew up together Dwayne we just grew up together.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: But me and Steve we kind of had a special bond he was like a brother more he was my first cousin he was like the brother that I didn't have and eventually I graduated from Francis T Nicholls. He graduated from John Mack we ended up going into the United States Marines together in 82 so we did that together and then we came out.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How many years were you in the marines?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: 3 years honorably discharged from out the Marines.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Are you still in touch with any of those guys?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Yes sir I'm definitely will my cousin Steve I'm definitely in touch with him he's in Texas my friend Jeronicus and his brother Jeronicus is not living but his brother has some kind of disability had as a result of a stroke.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: So I'm not in contact with him but I do have the phone number to his sister but I don't really call it too much. Just my cousin my cousin and my sister and my brother are kind of like the only people I'm in contact with my mom and dad both passed away in the 30 years I've been incarcerated.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you have regular visits?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Yeah. A friend of mine who comes and visit me regular like I said my sister she's going through something with cancer so she's suffering with that, my brother he comes every now and then not regularly. He just doesn't like the visiting shed up at Angola but that's about the extent. My friend really comes regularly about twice a month.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you have a specific memory of school?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: I think the best year that I had in high school at FT Nicholls I think not since I've been incarcerated the name changed to Ben Franklin no excuse me Frederick Douglass it was right there on St. Claude but I think the greatest year I had was in 1980 and I've really been trying to get my friends to get me the yearbook because I don't even have a picture of it.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: I won best dressed that year I was in a program my junior year of high school called distributive education. I had a job at Shoe Town right next to the Saenger Theater during that particular time and I was able to wear suits and ties and just go to school like that and go to 3 classes and then catch the St. Claude bus go to my job. Eventually my daddy got me a moped so I was bringing that to school.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: I was following this trend they had with it GQ they had all these cars driving mopeds around so I got one of them and that's what I was doing. That's like the greatest year I think I had in school. Eventually next year in 81 I graduated from Francis T Nicholls.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. And then the Marine Corps so did you have a new brushes with the law before this?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Man none. I think the only time that I ever ever had a problem with the law was my daddy got me an ST 70 Honda motorcycle and I was way in East New Orleans.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That's a dirt bike isn't it?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: It's a dirt bike, but it has the blinkers and the, you can ride it on the street.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah it's street legal.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: So I'm like 13 years old and I'm way in the East of New Orleans and we got the bikes parked out there and the police pass and they're like asking us where we from. I told him that I was way from Independence and Galvez no driver's license or anything they didn't put me to jail or anything but they put me in the back of the car and brought me to my house where I probably got the worst whipping I'd probably ever received.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: My dad got the truck and went to pick up the bike and brought it back, but that's the only time I ever had a problem with the police my whole childhood life.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah so this one event in your life has now come to define the rest of your life.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Well, not the one event cause I would like to say this here what happened in my life was nothing growing up my mom and dad did an excellent job with that I really feel bad that I let them down, but after I got out of the service I worked for my father who was a paint contractor was painting the Mirabeau apartments and he was painting the East River apartments in Michaud and around 86, 87.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: This is the greatest defining part of my life. I was coming out of the Calliope Projects I was driving a 1984 Camaro. I was coming out of the Calliope Projects and right there in Tulane and Broad I'm talking about I just seen the most beautiful chick you ever wanted to see. She's like just sitting there. I pull over and she gets in the car and we're talking and she introduces me to crack.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: That really just took my life to one point to a whole another level and this had to be like 86 I fell in 88 so like 86 I get her in the car we drive to the Superdome Motel right there on Tulane Avenue and I'm drinking, I'm drinking a beer and I've never used cocaine heroin I've never even seen it before. I've seen marijuana but I've never seen cocaine or heroin earlier than 86.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: And once she was telling me about what cocaine does and how great it makes you perform in the bed I tried it. And man I tried that never try and any other drugs before, that drug was like I don't know how you can just grab something that's like meant for you something you just couldn't get away from.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Because the first time I smoked it that night I smoked it a couple times that night with her we had sex. And the next morning I went to work with my dad and I was climbing up the ladder and I'll never forget this feeling never ever using a drug before I just couldn't wait for an opportunity to find her again to just get some more. And from there my life just went upside down.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: That was the defining point of my life. Because at that point my dad was paying me he was paying me nice money probably like $60 a day. I'm making $300 a day I mean $300 a week and if I work the weekend 420 and I'm talking about some points it just got to a point where I got paid on Friday I probably wouldn't even wake up Saturday with any money.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: That's what's like the most defining point in my life. It brought me into an environment that I have never been a part of; it took me back to the projects where I never was raised at, and then my whole life just changed. Just surviving just for the purpose of just using crack.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: And it lasted for like 24 months of just going downhill I mean to a point where by me knowing who I was and knowing how I'm living.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: I'm not I'm really speaking to the point where my mom and my dad they know that my life has changed; the responsibility they had given me they took that back.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: My dad's truck no way in the world he let me get behind this truck and bring it anywhere where before my addiction.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: They knew what was going on.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Yeah they knew it was gone yeah I can remember one time going over The St Claude overpass I just felt like jumping off because I just felt like I mean I couldn't stop. At one point my mom brought me to the vet rehab center to try and get control but that's from those the turning point in my life I just wanted to say that because like I said a lot of times.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Right now I'm involved in a lot of rehabilitation efforts and I hear guys they tell me about the problems I had home the problems they didn't have a mom didn't have a dad and it kind of makes me feel bad I had all of that. But that's what changed my life.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure yeah you describe that very well.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Thank you.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you have children?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Yeah I have a daughter. I left my daughter at 2 years old in fact I got married, my baby mama and she is my wife but I married her in the effort to try to slow down with the crack use. I just thought maybe if I just had some kind of level of responsibility maybe I would stop doing it for that because she was pregnant for me and she had the baby but after my life became unmanageable and out of control I just was trying to search for some kind of way.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Just to hold on and I tried that. I married her and we moved into an apartment and it was there that I committed the second degree murder. It was over drugs that's all that's the downfall. Right there.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So obviously one of the reasons that we are talking with you is that you've been identified as this person who's a model inmate. You've turned your life around like you said it's not the typical story of all these terrible things and then coming to Angola, but certainly you had reached a low point in your life with respect to drugs.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: All the way to the ground.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You are now, 30 years later obviously a very different person, so when you think back on the person that was brought here how would you describe that man?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: When I first came into the system, prison, not taking responsibility, it was everybody fault except mine. Systematically I was being pointed out because I was black I was being given this life sentence because I was black I was it was everybody's fault never taking responsibility never realized that the reason that I'm here a hundred percent based on just me and me alone. So as the first couple years I was here the negativity just came in.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: I had thought everything the correctional officers to even certain inmates were working with the system it all part of this conspiracy. I was really negative I was out the 9th ward in greater than ever before from being in that geographical area I wanted to demonstrate that I was from out the 9th Ward and I just was like that type of person real negative, real destructive and it just continued it on and it continued on and continued on my mom is coming to see me all the time my dad's coming to see me all the time here to bring my daughter.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: I just continued down that path until one day my dad, my dad wound up dying. And my dad was a breadwinner. Like I said my mom really didn't work so that just turned everything around the economic aspect and everything even I remember one time my dad had died my mom was telling me she had to cut off the insurance that would have automatically pay for the house to try to manage some type of money to help my dad so after hearing those things it kind of brought a level of identifying me as the person that was responsible for these circumstances.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: It wasn't nobody else it was me it was me that was unavailable for my daddy what I'm saying it was me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I think that's one of the hardest parts about serving such a long sentence is that all this stuff happening that you can't do anything about outside.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: With your family especially I think. So, some people can point to a specific event, might have been the death of your father or a specific interaction with a person who teaches them something or some kind of light bulbs that goes on and they just switch, turn their lives around. Was it kind of like that for you or was it more gradual?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: I think it was kind of like that with me because like I'm saying all before my negativity was sort of being there I spent a lot of time visiting my mom behind the screen. Well now because my dad no longer there I wanted to be at the table with her I wanted to be able to hold her so I spent less time being negative and more time being positive. Kind of change with the flow of people I hung with I got more caught up.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: I'm inmate counsel now I caught a more caught up with guys that were more interested in reading case law I got into the paralegal course that existed up here in Angola. And then I kind of like just kept on going and I just never stopped. And now it's like I understand life so much better while I'm 53 is supposed to then I was 24 but today I just learned I know life so much better it's like knowing who I was and the things that I was involved with the 2 years that fall to crack cocaine the beginning part of my incarcerated.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: It's like you kind of understand certain activities you don't want to be a part of because it effects of it the results of it or not going to be favorable for you. And I think my dad passing kind of made me want to be that for my mom and be the type of man I should have always wanted to be. At that point I was just thinking about her.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: You coming up here I want to be at the table with you want to be able to hold and I want to do everything right and then in wanting to do that got involved with more positive things that started just bringing things to my attention.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: And believe it or not even that I was in the Marines and I travel all around the world I've been to Korea, Okinawa, just being in prison and understanding life critical thinking in different little situations learning how the law works and how things you do how people I mean just certain things that you just have to do.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: You want it like right now in prison I have a life sentence you want to keep yourself in position just on the narrow possibility that you might go home you want to prepare yourself through skills that could give you the opportunity to work once you do get home. You want to be thinking about what you eating because you don't want to do anything to cause you to get sick what I'm saying.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Under no circumstances do you want to be controlled by a substance again. I mean that's like terrifying just to think at one point that's the way I was. I mean it just that life I would never ever pursue that again.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How far into your sentence did this change happen with your dad dying?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Well I came to jail in 88 and my Dad died in 94. And it this that the 94 to at least like 2000, I just was on my grind just learning things just after learning one thing I wanted to learn other things and other things I learned.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So yeah that was pretty, sometimes it takes folks a little longer than 6 years or so into your sentence to get you the point where you're like I've got to do something different

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Right. I guess yeah I think it was maybe the love I had for my dad and the love definitely I had for my mom and like I said just wanting to be there

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah and I think the passing of a parent is a profound experience when you're incarcerated I'm sure. Is that reflected in your conduct record do? Can you did you see like bad conduct up to 94 and then phew smooth sailing.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: If you looked at my conduct jacket I think in the last 15 years I might have 3 write-ups maybe 3 or 4 maybe for the most but a my first six years I probably had every bit of 35 write ups. I mean there were days when I would just lay in the bed and I wouldn't hell I wouldn't even go to work just nothing mattered everything was just another thought.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Then like I said there were so many times my mom came up here I was either in a Cell Block visiting behind screens or long ago used to be able to go to the visiting shed but to have to wear dungeon attire It would be all wrinkled never your size but that's the way I spent my time visiting.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So part of it was also to get a good conduct record so that you could visit your mom.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Well actually to stay out of the dungeon to not be locked up because once you if I did anything right here in population the first thing they do is carry me to the administrative segregation part put me in a cell and if this weekend and had come and somebody came to visit me if they take me out of the cell and bring me behind the screen to go visit.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: And she was like she never did show me that that really concerned her before but after my dad passed when I wish I had to sit there behind the screen one time I seen her crying I couldn't even hold her.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: So I kind of like well when I know you're coming I'm just not going to never be in the dungeon and then it just became, I'm just going to stop being the dungeon all together. Then once I start getting involved in other activities I had no need of going into the dungeon.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So tell me a little bit about what you're daily life is like and what organizations you're with, what's your life like in Angola now?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Right now I'm a disciplinary counsel. So what I ensure is that everybody that get wrote up that they get a fair due process hearing. That's my responsibility I kind of like base that on the decision that I don't try to judge or anything like that I just make sure that they get a fair hearing. After DB Court I'm kinda involved with teaching other guys an understanding of law trying to give them that head up that I got.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: This is the way the law work this is the way our circumstances work if you ever hope to go home you have to understand this. I mean there's no doubt you go back for an evidentiary hearing you don't want to be that same person sitting in the courtroom where everybody's talking over your head.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Everything's a procedure's or a regulated practice and if you just kind of, you're never be a lawyer but if you just kind of understand you can make better decisions. If you the type of person that has a crime like I have where I had confessed without a doubt that I committed the offense there's nothing in the court that's going to come about.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: So you actually the only thing you could possibly live for is the possibility of making pardon. The possibility of a law passing. That brings me to another point that I do I try to organize different efforts where guys come together and focus groups to kind of understand that even that are circumstances that present, they tell us never going home I will never stop us with networking with our family members in an effort to try to pass legislation that will help us get parole eligibility and stuff and my whole day is just based on that and that alone that's what I do every day.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay so you must have learned quite a bit from Calvin Duncan over the years.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: 100% Calvin Duncan definitely changed the landscape of prison litigation because at one point when I first started reading law and applying law we had no concept about procedures and regulations all we just new is our constitutional right may have been violated this way and we just push it right to the court.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: But Calvin try to put us in point where look the state legislation on the federal Congress is actually implementing regulations to kind of like what everything in the time in the prospective certain vehicles that you could put certain issues on and it really helped us.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Because now we're getting answers on a merits instead of getting all these numbers like 9.30 9.29 we're actually getting the merits of our claim addressed. And that's the philosophy that we continue on through the prison population is trying to get guys look. If you're going to get denied get denied on your merit not because you're too late not because you're not correct just on the merits of your claim.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: He's taught me so much I mean I just I feel lucky to know him.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Yeah I have definitely he had an impact on my life.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: He'll be here on Thursdays by the way for the next foreseeable month or two so one of the things that were trying to do and you've just said something about this to the idea that you keep hope alive, you educate yourself so that should there be a way that you can contribute to the conversation on parole eligibility for lifers that maybe that day will come then you'll be ready to go.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: In the meantime there, I have trouble understanding how so many people cope in the face of a life without parole sentence. How do you cope with it?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Well I cope with it with the hope and the possibility like you said of knowing guys like Calvin Duncan, Norris. Since my incarceration they've always been like leaders and vanguards of my life and I've seen them go home, Reetos, Chico Yancys. And I feel certain that at some point that I have a chance to go home but like you said I mean it's two sides of every story, just like you see me before you saying that I know that we have to change laws.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: I know that it's a possibility we live in a democratic government that we could model our laws even after the England and the British laws that provide opportunity and change like most of the states in the nation there are guys that feel that despair that live with that every day I represent them every day and DB Court they don't care if the sun come up or whatever happens they feel like their life is over. But I'm not one of them. I used to be one of them.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: I'm just hoping that things like what we're doing here and possibility of guys like yourself of making things happen and hopefully I have the opportunity that one chance to go in front of that board to show them that I'm worthy of being given that second chance. Just hoping, that's what I'm living for. And even in the meantime all that's going on I think I'm doing my civic duty to educate as many guys that's coming in the system at how this government and our laws really work.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: How to continue this fight not to stop. Because I could die tomorrow. We still need guys in here who understand law because we're not rich we're not going to go buy lawyers or nothing like that. You got to kind of understand some things by yourself. I mean like for instance you're not even granted a right to an attorney on collateral review so you got to know how to put together a post-conviction somewhat.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: And knowing that 15, 574.4 says right now the only way I'll be able to go in front of the parole board is if my sentence gets commuted to a fixed term of years that provision has to change. It has to. We had a warden that was here Warden Cane and he made his speech he said 85% of the guys that's in Angola are going to die here.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: And after he made that speech, heroin lifers were given parole, juvenile non-violent lifers were given parole, Miller came about act 401 just recently act 469 just came into effect with the 15 308 and it's like all those guys just going out and the day we go to the rodeo's like a big old family reunion that guys that have been here for years and years are coming through the gates and they're doing positive things out there and I'm just hoping just for my chance to get outside.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: We all was in the farm line together at one point even on the compound on the east yard all the different camps. And these guys are free for real. With life sentences. The same sentence I have. And they're not violating they're not causing any harm to the world they're just doing the things they're supposed to do.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So on the other side of this this is what everybody tells me is the victims. So then when you look back you've served 30 years of your life. When you look back on the victim and what brought you here I mean is it possible to even feel remorse after being punished for 30 years for something like that?

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Well let me say this from understanding that I have now. A lot of time you find judges that abused their discretion and me taking somebody's life really gave me I really abused my discretion really I mean I have no right to decide who lives who dies and I mean like I said early on you kind of justified while this guy is this type of person but now none of that matters I made a decision that took somebody son off the Earth somebody's father maybe off the Earth and that's a decision that only God should be able to make not me.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: So of course just thinking like that I know I really messed up. I know it's serious and I know whether people real close to him will ever probably forgive me I don't know. I just like to tell them I'm sorry. I'd like to tell his family I'm sorry and I mean I didn't have a right to do that I understand the victim's perspective and I guess there are victims in Louisiana there are victims in other states and in other states and other countries have parole eligibility.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: They got a kind of like I mean I don't know I'm a victim in a circumstance because I have family members that were killed in New Orleans and these guys are right here around me now. It doesn't matter if I forgive them or not it's just the fact that they're doing what they need to do and they're trying to go home and I wouldn't stand in their way. What I'm saying.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: I would hope that this family member understands that I'm sorry and I will when I been in time in jail I've been doing my best to make a better person and if I'm ever released back in society I'll be that person that will try to slow down or curb other people from making the same mistakes that I made. The same thing I do here.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: No different I mean it's like from being a marine to being a person that my parents raised, made me understand that the only thing that we all need to do in life is try to better our situation.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Not personally but the whole community thing just whatever I can do to make these circumstances better. It'd be the same mindset if I was ever released into society I wouldn't lay down I would do the same thing to make my community better try to cause younger people from not making the same wrong decisions that I made if I could give it any kind of help be in any kind of position help guys up here to possibly seek their freedom I mean something, I just don't think that life exists to not try to make things better. You shouldn't just be relying on government officials, judges.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
transcript.content: Each person should have a role that they're doing just like in here I'm not waiting on the mental health section of the prison or the wardens or the security guards. I have a class myself that I have 30 or 40 people in it and I'm telling them these are the better things to be doing with your life right now. I'm not waiting on anybody. I know what's best. I know what freedom is foremost in your mind these are the things that you have to be doing.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. What about the logic of the Supreme Court for juveniles? They recommend 25 years for parole eligibility no matter what you did.

transcript.speaker: Arthur
